div.p: Lee Berger has spent his professional life searching for evidence of our human past.
He is a paleoanthropologist who studies and searches for the graves and fossil remains of ancient humans.
He's done most of his work in Africa, but it was during a vacation on the Pacific island of Palau,
on a walk through one of its many caves, that he made an astonishing find.
"You see that? This is just packed full of bone. I mean you can actually see there's still some actually exposed here."
"But what's cool is that there was a whole skull here."
Berger thinks these bones may be the remains of some of the earliest humans ever to populate these islands.
Previous estimates trace the earliest humans found here by Berger to about twenty-nine hundred years ago.
But all the bones previously found by Berger were above something called a "flowstone."
A flowstone is a common phenomenon in caves, where water flowing over the ground deposits minerals that harden into stone.
All of Berger's previous digging was above a flowstone that dated back about twenty-nine hundred years.
Today, Berger has returned and is going to break through the flowstone.
He hopes that he will find bones from an even earlier age underneath the flowstone.
"We hope these dates are going to come out over the three thousand year mark."
Under the flowstone, Berger finds several human bones...including a tooth and a piece of human skull.
From these findings Berger can learn a lot more about early humans than just their age.
The bones he has inspected have some very unusual features:
a small chin, large teeth and what appears to be a small brain size...
inspiring Berger to reconsider his notion of what early humans looked like.
Berger believes that his Palau discoveries are new evidence of the wide variety of early human features in this region.
Berger's discoveries may also have significance for another set of bones found in the region:
those of a tiny human that researchers call "the hobbit," after the small creatures in Tolkien's story, Lord of the Rings.
Its scientific name is Homo floresiensis.
Debate continues over this controversial discovery. Contrary to some researchers,
Berger believes the hobbits might not be a separate species of human, but just another variation of the same species.
"It is also making me personally consider my understanding of what is normal human variation."
Berger published a paper suggesting the bones he found are astonishing because they show how varied early humans were in their size and shape.
This new understanding of the potential for human variation makes some people doubt whether the hobbit is a special species.
The controversies will likely continue. But in the meantime, Berger will return.
"What has struck me on this second scientific visit is how phenomenally little research has been done on these islands."
Berger hopes to change that in the coming years, by continuing his search for more definitive answers to our human past.
